title: 114_hr2750
content: The Act titled "Improved Security Vetting for Aviation Workers Act of 2015" amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 by adding a new section for vetting aviation workers. The Administrator, in coordination with the Director of National Intelligence, requested access to additional terrorism-related data from TIDE to enhance the credential vetting program for individuals with airport access. Security Inspectors were directed to annually review airport badging procedures, including Criminal History Records Checks, to improve security measures. The Administrator may conduct a pilot program of the Rap Back Service with the FBI to notify of status changes for individuals with airport access. The program aims to tailor information to only notify of disqualifying offenses under the credential vetting program. The Administrator may conduct a pilot program with the FBI for the Rap Back Service to notify of status changes for individuals with airport access. The program will ensure compliance with regulations for fingerprint-based criminal history records checks and investigation procedures. The Administrator will submit a determination to Congress regarding the implementation of the Rap Back Service for airport access, including costs and consultation with the Chief Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Officer to align retention periods of personal and biometric information. The Administrator will issue guidance for airport badging authorities to set expiration dates on credentials based on lawful work authorization. They will also review credential denials related to lawful status and coordinate with airports to address weaknesses. Upon completion, the Administrator will brief Congress. The Administrator will brief Congress on determinations and reviews required under this section. A clerical amendment is made to the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Administrator of the Transportation Security Administration will provide a report to Congress on the status of plans for a pilot program with the FBI on the Rap Back Service within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. The report will detail the requirements and goals of the program. The House of Representatives passed the bill on July 27, 2015. Karen L. Haas is the Clerk.
